quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Some examples include their priorities in product roadmap are driven by a 100-year vision that comes from Tobi, the CEO.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights Shopify’s long-horizon planning model as a guiding framework for product prioritization.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: And the core product teams don't have metrics or KPIs. They're essentially banned. And instead, decisions are made based on taste, and intuition, and building towards this long-term vision.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A contrarian approach to product decision-making that deprioritizes KPIs in favor of qualitative judgment and vision alignment.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Also, the growth team optimizes for churn, which is unlike any other company I've ever come across. And once you hear why, this will make a lot of sense.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Challenges conventional growth optimization by centering churn as the primary lever rather than acquisition or conversion.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Also, they keep long-term holdouts for every experiment they run, and they automatically look at the impact these experiments have had on the business a year later, two years later, and three years later, and then revisit these decisions down the road.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Describes an experimentation methodology designed to capture long-term effects that typical short-window A/B tests miss.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: So overall, we're about 10% of e-commerce in the United States.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: A concrete scale data point that contextualizes Shopify’s market footprint and relevance of its practices.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Building analytics from scratch can be time-consuming, expensive, and a really challenging process. Enter Explo.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A clear build-vs-buy framing that highlights the hidden cost and complexity of rolling your own analytics.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Once you're ready, simply embed the dashboard or report into your application with a tiny code snippet.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A practical implementation detail that reduces perceived integration friction for embedded analytics.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The best part, your end users can use Explo's AI features for their own report and dashboard generation, eliminating customer data requests for your support team.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: An operational leverage idea: shift reporting workload from support to self-serve AI for customers.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You can even recruit from over 3 million participants directly in Dovetail.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete scale data point that suggests a faster path to user research recruiting without separate tooling.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: My sense or my understanding is you guys are kind of the opposite. You one, don't think tons about churn, you almost optimize for churn.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A contrarian growth/retention setup that challenges the default assumption that churn should always be minimized.

quotes.topic_title: Why Shopify optimizes for churn
quotes.text: But most businesses do ultimately fail. And so the way we look at it is can we lower the barriers to getting started and get as many people in the door trying their hand at entrepreneurship?
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: A counterintuitive growth strategy: optimize for more attempts (even if many fail) by reducing friction to start.

quotes.topic_title: Why Shopify optimizes for churn
quotes.text: And the way the Shopify business model works is we do charge a subscription, but most of our revenue comes from payments, which is tied to directly to a merchant's success.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Shows how aligning monetization with customer success can justify different retention/churn priorities than typical SaaS.

quotes.topic_title: Why Shopify optimizes for churn
quotes.text: Some of those people on their first attempt that's entrepreneurship might not succeed, but the folks who do go on to be successful will make that entire cohort of merchants who started something that makes Shopify as a business extremely successful.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: A cohort-level mental model where a few breakout winners drive the economics for everyone who tries.

quotes.topic_title: Why Shopify optimizes for churn
quotes.text: Correct. And that's really a different insight than most SaaS companies that they get a customer, they really never want that person to leave. And we want to lower that barriers to get started and be successful.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Directly challenges the standard SaaS retention-first playbook and reframes the goal around enabling success at scale.

quotes.topic_title: Why Shopify optimizes for churn
quotes.text: When you can think of the other parallel is in angel investing, right? Most of angel investments are not going to work out, but the couple that do make that entire investment portfolio successful.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: A memorable analogy practitioners can use to reason about power-law outcomes and portfolio-style growth bets.

quotes.topic_title: Measuring success via cohort GMV power laws
quotes.text: This way is thinking about a cohort of users we acquire in a given time period, say a quarter. And then over the next year, two years, three years, four years, five years, how much GMV have those merchants produced in total?
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Introduces a cohort-based, long-horizon methodology for measuring growth success via total value created rather than short-term retention.

quotes.topic_title: Measuring success via cohort GMV power laws
quotes.text: Not about per merchant basis, but in total, did that cohort generate GMV?
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: A counterintuitive metric choice: optimize for cohort-level aggregate outcomes instead of average performance per user.

quotes.topic_title: Measuring success via cohort GMV power laws
quotes.text: And GMV is a power law based metric. And so it's really that power law that drives the success of each cohort.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Frames success as driven by outliers, implying strategies should account for power-law dynamics rather than uniform improvements.

quotes.topic_title: Measuring success via cohort GMV power laws
quotes.text: Again, going back to investing, same thing there. Each vintage from a fund, how much did that return as a fund? And it's really driven by the few really successful outliers.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Provides an investing analogy that operationalizes the power-law mental model for evaluating cohorts like fund vintages.

quotes.topic_title: Measuring success via cohort GMV power laws
quotes.text: So this begs the question, that sounds like a very long feedback loop.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights the practical tradeoff of long-horizon cohort GMV measurement: slower learning cycles despite better alignment with true value.

quotes.topic_title: Long feedback loops and long-term holdouts
quotes.text: I think with Shopify, we very purposely set up different parts of the org to think on very different time horizons and with very different ways of thinking about how to build product and the like.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: A practical org-design framework: intentionally separate teams by time horizon to avoid one-size-fits-all metrics and planning.

quotes.topic_title: Long feedback loops and long-term holdouts
quotes.text: So we constantly will relook at an experiment a year later, see that the way the GMV curve for the distribution was different than we might've originally thought.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: A concrete methodology for long feedback loops: revisit experiments a year later to validate whether effects persist or change.

quotes.topic_title: Long feedback loops and long-term holdouts
quotes.text: And so there's a lot of longterm monitoring of experiments over these very long time horizons to both inform what those input metrics are and more importantly hold ourselves accountable to, did we actually move what we cared about, which is that longterm GMV, in the right way?
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Highlights accountability via long-term holdouts and using downstream outcomes to refine leading indicators.

quotes.topic_title: Long feedback loops and long-term holdouts
quotes.text: And I would encourage everyone, if you can, look at some of the experiments that you thought were your biggest winners. Look at the downstream metrics for a year, two years on that experiment. And I'll bet you'd be surprised how many times the metric is different than what you thought it would be after a year.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Actionable, counterintuitive advice: many “winning” experiments look different (or reverse) when measured on longer horizons.

quotes.topic_title: How often short-term lifts disappear later
quotes.text: And then you look a year later, and there's actually no incremental lift on GMV from that cohort.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Highlights why long-term holdouts matter: early activation lifts can fail to translate into durable business value.

quotes.topic_title: How often short-term lifts disappear later
quotes.text: A lot of the time it's actually more pull-forward effect, than you fully realize or an incremental user that's just really not worth that much.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Provides a practical mental model for interpreting short-term metric lifts as timing shifts or low-value acquisition rather than true growth.

quotes.topic_title: How often short-term lifts disappear later
quotes.text: there are cases, and these are the most interesting ones, where you realize that you uncovered a pocket of merchants that are actually extremely valuable entrepreneurs who go on to be successful, that you missed in your normal short-term measurement techniques.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Shows how long-term measurement can reveal hidden high-LTV segments that short-term metrics systematically overlook.

quotes.topic_title: How often short-term lifts disappear later
quotes.text: If you think about in a business case, if I give you a little monetary boost and reduce that monetary friction, I can actually causally change your ability to become successful, because I've given you a little bit more time to try that idea a little bit longer.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Actionable mechanism: reducing early monetary friction can increase downstream success by extending the runway for new entrepreneurs.

quotes.topic_title: How often short-term lifts disappear later
quotes.text: Yeah, it's in the 30 to 40% range.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Concrete benchmark for practitioners: a sizable share of early experiment lifts may disappear when evaluated a year later.

quotes.topic_title: Monetary friction and unlocking valuable merchants
quotes.text: Yeah, I think a lot of this has to do with, we call it monetary friction.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Introduces a useful framework (“monetary friction”) for diagnosing early-stage drop-off and merchant failure.

quotes.topic_title: Monetary friction and unlocking valuable merchants
quotes.text: So one of the hardest things to do with a business is when you're getting started, is you might not have any revenue coming in, and you are kind of bootstrapping, which in Shopify's case might be 39 bucks a month. But still, it's a real expense.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Grounds the concept in a concrete example and highlights how even “small” fees can be meaningful early on.

quotes.topic_title: Monetary friction and unlocking valuable merchants
quotes.text: The common belief is that we'll usually get lower quality folks coming in the door, because usually discounts are associated with lower quality.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Surfaces a conventional assumption teams often use to argue against discounts/trials, setting up a counterpoint.

quotes.topic_title: Monetary friction and unlocking valuable merchants
quotes.text: If you think about in a business case, if I give you a little monetary boost and reduce that monetary friction, I can actually causally change your ability to become successful, because I've given you a little bit more time to try that idea a little bit longer.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Actionable product/growth lever: reducing early cost can directly increase success by extending runway for experimentation.

quotes.topic_title: Monetary friction and unlocking valuable merchants
quotes.text: And so often in those types of experiments you see that you've basically unlocked a class of people who might've given up without reducing that monetary friction
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: A practical experimentation takeaway: lowering early monetary barriers can reveal “hidden” high-potential users who would otherwise churn.

quotes.topic_title: Advice when you can’t run long holdouts
quotes.text: So as deep as you can go in the funnel for as long as you can wait. Do that.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: A simple measurement heuristic: push evaluation as far downstream (and as long) as practical to better predict true impact.

quotes.topic_title: Advice when you can’t run long holdouts
quotes.text: And if you can't, you know what I would say? Still you should just bet on, if something is showing lift up funnel, still ship it and it's probably not going to hurt you, but don't overestimate the amount of impact that this is having.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Pragmatic guidance for teams without long holdouts: ship short-term winners, but calibrate expectations about their true contribution.

quotes.topic_title: Advice when you can’t run long holdouts
quotes.text: Because if you didn't move the short-term impact, you're not going to have the long-term lift.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: A strong rule-of-thumb linking short-term movement to long-term outcomes, helping teams decide when waiting longer is unlikely to change the conclusion.

quotes.topic_title: Advice when you can’t run long holdouts
quotes.text: I've seen neutral be positive, but I haven't seen negative.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation about risk: neutral short-term results can improve over time, but rarely flip to negative long-term.

quotes.topic_title: Shopify’s holdout design and experiment tooling
quotes.text: Two things. We have two layers of holdouts. So one is more the holdouts of every change in a quarter, holdout 5% across the board.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Introduces a layered holdout methodology that institutionalizes long-term measurement across all changes, not just individual experiments.

quotes.topic_title: Shopify’s holdout design and experiment tooling
quotes.text: Second is for changes that only affect new merchants, what we'll do is we'll take that group of folks, let's call it 50/50 split, and then run that for a few weeks. And then what we're doing, we look at the long-term effects is actually ship the winner to 100%, but we're looking at the cohort of folks who was assigned to the experiment. We're going back and looking at those people who were assigned a year later.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Describes a practical way to ship quickly while still preserving a clean cohort for long-term impact evaluation.

quotes.topic_title: Shopify’s holdout design and experiment tooling
quotes.text: So it allows us to still ship, get stuff out, but we've kind of held the experiment in a way that allows us to see those long-term effects just for the cohort that was exposed.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Captures the core mental model: decouple shipping velocity from long-term measurement by tracking the originally assigned cohort.

quotes.topic_title: Shopify’s holdout design and experiment tooling
quotes.text: And then in our experimentation tools, all experimenters are paying that three months, six months, nine months, 12 months with here are the updated results. So you can't really get hide from, what did this really result in over a longer term horizon?
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Shows an accountability mechanism—automated follow-ups—that prevents teams from ignoring long-term outcomes after launch.

quotes.topic_title: Growth wins: onboarding personalization and friction
quotes.text: Going back, there's always a lot of value in thinking through monetary friction as I mentioned. That's always going to be something to export. Trial dynamics, different types of incentives, all of those things are very impactful.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Highlights a repeatable experimentation lever—monetary friction and incentive design—that can drive outsized impact across products.

quotes.topic_title: Growth wins: onboarding personalization and friction
quotes.text: But just the nuts and bolts of sign up, collecting the right information. And you usually want to collect more information than most people think you do in your sign up flow. If you can then leverage that to personalize the guidance.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Counterintuitively argues for collecting more signup info—if used for personalization—to improve onboarding outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Growth wins: onboarding personalization and friction
quotes.text: But the amount of impact by just nailing those flows has never ceased to amaze me and setting up that person for long-term success.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Emphasizes that polishing signup/onboarding flows can produce surprisingly large, durable gains.

quotes.topic_title: Growth wins: onboarding personalization and friction
quotes.text: What we get very nervous about is the easiest way to increase retention is always to constrict the funnel stage one above the retention metric you're trying to optimize for.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Offers a cautionary mental model: retention can be “improved” by narrowing the funnel upstream, which may be a misleading optimization.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding funnel-rate traps with absolute metrics
quotes.text: What we get very nervous about is the easiest way to increase retention is always to constrict the funnel stage one above the retention metric you're trying to optimize for.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Highlights a common metric-gaming trap: improving a downstream rate by adding friction upstream.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding funnel-rate traps with absolute metrics
quotes.text: The simplest way to increase my signup to activated thing is just make it harder to sign up.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: A memorable, counterintuitive example of how conversion-rate optimization can incentivize worse user experience.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding funnel-rate traps with absolute metrics
quotes.text: orienting every team to think about the total number of people, not the rate, but the total number of people who got to the end of their part of the journey is a very powerful way to incentivize people to do the right thing
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Provides a practical metric framework: use absolute counts to align incentives across funnel stages.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding funnel-rate traps with absolute metrics
quotes.text: Because that will always hurt your conversion rate, but it may actually give you more people on the outside.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Encourages teams to accept lower rates if it increases total throughput and overall growth.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding funnel-rate traps with absolute metrics
quotes.text: No, your CAC also went down by probably more.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: A concrete reminder to evaluate unit economics holistically—lower friction can reduce CAC even if LTV/retention rates dip.

quotes.topic_title: Defining monetary friction
quotes.text: So things like trial, trial dynamics, trial length, trial amount.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Breaks “monetary friction” into concrete, tunable trial levers teams can adjust to reduce early barriers to adoption.

quotes.topic_title: Defining monetary friction
quotes.text: It means incentives.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Highlights incentives as a core component of monetary friction, not just pricing, expanding what practitioners can optimize.

quotes.topic_title: Defining monetary friction
quotes.text: So what is in your product? What do people value and need in order to be successful?
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: A practical diagnostic question for designing incentives/credits that actually drive user success and retention.

quotes.topic_title: Defining monetary friction
quotes.text: So in Shopify's case, that might be app score credits or things like that, but those are the two forms of monetary friction we talk about and then of course actual price point.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Provides a concrete example (Shopify credits) and frames monetary friction as trials + incentives + price point.

quotes.topic_title: How Shopify’s growth org is structured
quotes.text: We have two big groups within growth. So one is what we call growth R&D. So this might be what you traditionally consider product design engineering, data, your traditional product teams. Then we have growth marketing, which in Shopify's case is paid acquisition, media buying, affiliate marketing, email, content, and SEO.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: A clear, reusable org design framework that separates growth into product-led (R&D) and channel-led (marketing) functions.

quotes.topic_title: How Shopify’s growth org is structured
quotes.text: Within growth R&D, three pillars. One is what we call growth products. And so this is basically everything from landing pages, sign up, onboarding, monetization. So trial, incentives, the like, all the way through to what we call our home feed, our engagement to basically get more merchants. Again, not necessarily to retain, but to keep giving entrepreneurship a try to become bigger and bigger businesses.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Defines “growth product” as full-lifecycle activation/monetization/engagement, with a nuanced goal beyond classic retention framing.

quotes.topic_title: How Shopify’s growth org is structured
quotes.text: Second is what we call our enable pillar, and this pillar is building tools for both growth and the rest of Shopify. So things like experimentation platform, our communication platform, our business intelligence tooling that powers a lot of what we're doing, our more tech work to support our growth marketing team.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Highlights an “enable” pillar as a force multiplier—centralizing experimentation, comms, and BI to scale growth execution.

quotes.topic_title: How Shopify’s growth org is structured
quotes.text: And then our third bucket, which is maybe a little different from most growth teams is actually our customer support, groups within growth. We want to think about customer support as part of this merchant journey of coming on, giving entrepreneurship a try, all the way through to here's the support I need as I'm becoming a multi-billion dollar business on Shopify.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: A counterintuitive org choice: treating support as a growth lever across the merchant journey, not a separate ops function.

quotes.topic_title: How Shopify’s growth org is structured
quotes.text: We build a tooling to make those support advisors superheroes. And then on the help center, all of our AI stuff to make a great customer experience for people who are just engaging in a self-serve. So it's the tooling and the experience for merchants.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Actionable approach to scaling support impact via tooling and self-serve/AI experiences rather than embedding agents in the growth org.

quotes.topic_title: Goals and measurement across growth teams
quotes.text: So yeah. So at the highest level we think about that total cohort value. We bring in a set of merchants in a given year. How much GMV, how much that set of merchants worth over the next three, four years to Shopify? And that's the most important thing that we want to focus on.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Defines a top-level growth metric (multi-year cohort value) that aligns acquisition with long-term business impact rather than short-term counts.

quotes.topic_title: Goals and measurement across growth teams
quotes.text: So that's the macro growth perspective. Cohort value over cost and payback. So that's the macro point of view.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Provides a concise measurement framework that pairs value creation with efficiency guardrails (cost and payback).

quotes.topic_title: Goals and measurement across growth teams
quotes.text: And then within growth marketing, each channel operates with certain guardrails around their LTV CACs.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Shows a practical way to decentralize decision-making by giving channels clear unit-economics constraints.

quotes.topic_title: Goals and measurement across growth teams
quotes.text: But because they're measured on absolutes and they really think about that absolute value, we don't get caught into, did your conversion rate over the course of this year go up or down? It's kind of irrelevant. What was the sum of the impact over a long period on that total cohort value that we're trying to produce from before merchants?
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Challenges the common focus on rate metrics by emphasizing long-horizon absolute value as the real scorecard.

quotes.topic_title: Goals and measurement across growth teams
quotes.text: We call. We call the experiment after three weeks, but in all cases, the group is held, we watch them. And that's where that ping comes back, every experiment is watched. And that ping comes back three, six months, 12 months to re-look at was this actually successful?
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Describes an experimentation methodology that balances fast shipping with long-term holdout accountability checks.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: That's three new products and a ton of AI features that make it faster and easier than ever before to truly get at the heart of what your customers want.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights a practical goal for customer research tooling: speed + depth in understanding customer needs.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: You can get a real-time pulse on what your customers are thinking with Dovetail's, automated feedback analysis platform, channels, or full summaries and insights from every customer interaction your team has ever had with their AI chatbot ask Dovetail.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Describes an actionable methodology: continuous, automated synthesis of customer feedback across all interactions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Dovetail wants to give everyone in their organization instant access to their customers at any time.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A memorable principle for customer-centric orgs: democratize customer insight access beyond research teams.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And then a year later you realize, "Oh, that didn't last."
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that short-term experiment wins can decay, so teams should validate durability over time.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I know you said maybe it's a third of the time.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete data point suggesting a meaningful share of apparent wins may not hold up on longer horizons.

quotes.topic_title: Examples: pull-forward wins and delayed GMV impact
quotes.text: And it's great learning and that's why we take it. It's like, wow, okay, now we really uncovered something and it's such a successful discovery. Wow, okay, we thought this thing. But now we learned it actually wasn't as true as we thought. Cool. What can we take from that and be smarter next time so we don't just double down on the wrong things?
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Reframes “failed” long-term results as valuable learning and a guardrail against doubling down on misleading short-term wins.

quotes.topic_title: Examples: pull-forward wins and delayed GMV impact
quotes.text: You look back six, 12 months. There was really no long-term lift. And why is that? Because there's really a little bit of a selection bias there that people who were letting that payment fail probably weren't actually that dedicated to this entrepreneurship craft. They may have updated their credit card, but they still really weren't in it.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Concrete “pull-forward win” example showing how short-term lifts can vanish due to selection bias in who responds to interventions.

quotes.topic_title: Examples: pull-forward wins and delayed GMV impact
quotes.text: However, when we looked longer term on that six months later, it had a pretty massive impact on the number of people who were selling and producing GMV. And why is that? Because it didn't likely really influence anyone to buy Shopify or pay for Shopify. But the people who used it created better stores that were higher converting, and so they got early sales. They actually converted one of their visitors and they got momentum, and they stuck with entrepreneurship a little bit longer. And we saw that in that opposite way.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Counterintuitive “neutral early, positive later” case where an experiment shows no conversion lift but drives long-term GMV via downstream momentum effects.

quotes.topic_title: Examples: pull-forward wins and delayed GMV impact
quotes.text: In our culture of the kind of aim heavy, if the intuition is right that this probably is helping merchants, why do we start with that the original control is better if it's neutral? Let's start with, what would we have shipped if we were a blank slate? And if it's neutral, actually neither is better, so let's just pick the one we feel better about and ship that.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: A decision rule/framework for shipping “neutral” experiment outcomes by defaulting to the blank-slate product and strong intuition rather than preserving the control.

quotes.topic_title: Aim heavy: 100-year mindset and principles
quotes.text: Embedded in all of our principles are make the best product in the world, make money to do more of one. Never reverse principles two and three.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: A simple operating framework for prioritizing product quality first and monetization second to sustain long-term growth.

quotes.topic_title: Aim heavy: 100-year mindset and principles
quotes.text: But it's an important reminder job is to build the best product for merchants over the long period of time. And then all of the metrics and the make money part of it, secondary to that.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Clarifies a durable decision rule: optimize for merchant value over time, and treat revenue/metrics as downstream outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Aim heavy: 100-year mindset and principles
quotes.text: It's very seductive I think in most companies, including in Shopify because we can support large enterprise businesses today, right? Big brands who want to get off an outdated solution and come over to Shopify. It's very easy to just say, "Oh, that's very concrete." There's an existing business, we want to have them come join Shopify.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Highlights a common trap: chasing “concrete” short-term enterprise wins that can distract from the core long-term strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Aim heavy: 100-year mindset and principles
quotes.text: But if you're thinking about the long-term 100 years from now, guess what? All of the big brands of today be out of business. And many of them will be out of business in 30, 40, 50 years.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: A counterintuitive long-horizon lens that reframes enterprise customers as transient and pushes focus toward enduring segments.

quotes.topic_title: Aim heavy: 100-year mindset and principles
quotes.text: The real success of Shopify is getting every business to start with us and go, but making that type of an investment and being so focused on that entrepreneur segment and making it easier is how we build a very, very long-term oriented company.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Defines the long-term growth strategy as winning at the start of the business lifecycle by investing in entrepreneurs’ ease and success.

quotes.topic_title: Technical architecture as strategy (Tobi reviews)
quotes.text: And in that conversation, so much of the conversation is about both the technical how. How are we building this in a way that allows for Shopify to have optionality in the technical decisions that we are making?
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: A practical review focus: scrutinize implementation choices specifically to preserve future optionality.

quotes.topic_title: Technical architecture as strategy (Tobi reviews)
quotes.text: And I think for Tobi, one of the things I've learned and so is that how, the technical architecture determines strategy in a technology company even more than the what and who we're building for.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: A counterintuitive strategic lens: architecture decisions can shape company strategy more than product intent or audience.

quotes.topic_title: Technical architecture as strategy (Tobi reviews)
quotes.text: If you build the right technical how and set yourself up to have a platform that can be adaptable, flexible, that is incredibly valuable over the long term. It means we will sometimes take longer to ship a feature. It means we'll not chase certain deals or what have you, but we're going to kind of make that investment.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: Explicit tradeoff guidance: accept slower shipping and foregone deals to invest in long-term platform flexibility.

quotes.topic_title: Technical architecture as strategy (Tobi reviews)
quotes.text: Yeah, I mean in the last one, it was great. We had a 30-minute discussion about how to build CSV importers for people coming over from different platforms, and it was all about are we using open source library, doing it internally, are we doing it in the core code base? Are we building a separate first party app to do it? It was incredible detail.
quotes.speaker: Archie Abrams
quotes.context: A concrete example of the methodology in action: deep architectural debate even for a seemingly non-differentiating feature.
